They have feathers, which allows them to fly over water, which was a big change compared to land birds. So that's another important event. After that, early mammals came along as well. Mammals evolved around 38-30 million years ago, and they have bones, hair, andgills. That's definitely a key event because mammals are more complex than birds and provided the foundation for many modern animals.

Lastly, early amphibians appeared around the same time as early mammals, but they're less complex than mammals. Amphibians can live both in water and on land, which was a big shift from diurnal behaviors in mammals. So putting it all together, the order would be: emergence of birds, then waterfowl, followed by mammals, and finally amphibians.

Option D: Emergence of dinosaurs, first mammals, first birds, first amphibians.
No, that's backwards. Dinosaurs came last; they emerged way later. So D is wrong.

H. Appearance of the first amphibians, the emergence of the first insects, the colonization of land by plants, and the rise of the first seed-bearing plants

I. Appearance of the first land mammals, the emergence of the first dinosaurs, the rise of the first marine algae, and the appearance of the first sharks

J. Appearance of first humans, the emergence of first birds, the rise of first insects, and the appearance of first mammals
